source.query: push-up to downward dog muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The Push-Up to Downward Dog is a dynamic flow that builds upper body pushing strength (chest, shoulders, triceps) and core stability in the push-up, transitioning into a full-body stretch that lengthens the posterior chain (hamstrings, calves, back) and opens the shoulders/chest, combining strength with mobility and coordinating the diaphragm and deep abdominals for better trunk stability, as noted by Robertson Training Systems (https://robertsontrainingsystems.com/blog/rts-coaching-push-downward-dog/) and this YouTube video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zlzmTx_l2Bk), improving coordination and revealing core weaknesses like rib flare. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked: 

• Push-Up Phase (Strength): Pectorals, Deltoids (shoulders), Triceps, Serratus Anterior, Core (abs, obliques), Glutes, Erector Spinae. 
• Downward Dog Phase (Stretch/Stability): Hamstrings, Calves (gastroc/soleus), Shoulders, Upper Back, Glutes, Feet, Chest (opening). 
• Transition (Coordination): Deep core (transverse abdominis), Diaphragm, Rhomboids, Traps (stabilization). [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns: 

1. Plank (Start): Body in a straight line, core braced, hips level. 
2. Elbow Bend/Lowering: Hips stay high, body moves as one unit down toward the floor (like a close-grip push-up). 
3. Press Up: Arms extend, pushing the body back up to a plank. 
4. Hinge & Extend (Plank to Downward Dog): From plank, send hips up and back, straightening legs as much as possible to form an inverted 'V' shape, heels driving down. 
5. Stretch/Hold: Hold the inverted 'V', stretching hamstrings and calves while opening the chest and shoulders. 
6. Return: Hips move forward, chest drops between hands, transitioning into a low push-up or upward dog, then back to plank to repeat or finish. [1, 4, 7, 9, 10, 11]  

Key Benefits: 

• Full-Body Integration: Connects upper body pushing with lower body stretching and core control. 
• Shoulder Mobility: Opens tight shoulders and improves thoracic spine extension, notes Robertson Training Systems. 
• Core & Breath: Reveals and improves coordination between the diaphragm and deep abdominals, preventing rib flare, say this Medium article and this other article. 
• Posterior Chain Lengthening: Stretches tight hamstrings and calves, beneficial for squat/deadlift mechanics. [1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 11]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://robertsontrainingsystems.com/blog/rts-coaching-push-downward-dog/
[2] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zlzmTx_l2Bk

[4] https://www.hingehealth.com/resources/articles/downward-dog/
[5] https://www.nike.com/a/what-muscles-do-pushups-work-out
[6] https://www.setforset.com/blogs/news/push-up-variations
[7] https://medium.com/in-fitness-and-in-health/the-anatomy-of-a-push-up-166587072a12
[8] https://fitnessvolt.com/downward-facing-dog/
[9] https://www.physio-pedia.com/Pushups
[10] https://fitbod.me/exercises/downward-dog-push-up
[11] https://www.bu.edu/wellness/six-reasons-to-practice-downward-dog/
